column4: Hey I'm trying to migrate my Ubuntu home server to another computer. The new computer has a raid array. If I just copy the entire contents of my previous installation onto a new installation on the raided hard drives... will that work?
it should sorta work. How are you going to transfer the data from one drive to the RAID array?
it has 1 ide channel so I was going to hook it up, mount them both from a live cd and transfer
are you going to dd from one drive to the other?
Fryguy: it's hardware raid, not fake raid. my new installation of Ubuntu on the new server boots flawlessly with RAID5
dd?
dd is a UNIX command to copy raw data from device to another
it's like ghost
Fryguy: hmm... I guess the worst that could happen is that I just reinstall
ahh... i was just going to cp -r /media/hda1
example... dd if=/dev/hdc of=/dev/sda
In that example, I just imaged the old drive to my RAID array
Fryguy/nhlinux: Could I just use gparted and cpoy the entire partition to the raid array?
nope
gparted won't do that
why? When I run "fdisk -l" I see the entire RAID array as 1 hard drive
if you want to replicate the contents of the original drive (including the boot sector and partition table) to your RAID array, dd is the command to use.
Fryguy: You can copy partitions to another disk in gparted
I've never seen that featyre before
ok, so if I use dd; what would be the syntax to that? Say my RAID array is /dev/sda1 and my old hdd is /dev/hda1
dd if=/dev/hda of=/dev/sda (if you want to copy from sector 0 to the very last sector of /dev/hda, the first drive).
ok thanks. I'll go ahead and try that now
I'll let you know if it works ;D
/sbin/dumpe2fs works as well.
